awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Research Experience in Behavioral Sciences of Transportation Issues
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded from the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program in the SBE Directorate. The REU program has both scientific and societal benefits, and it integrates research and education. The goal of this REU Site on transportation in the behavioral sciences is to provide a diverse group of undergraduate researchers with training on research skills in various subfields of Psychology and Engineering that contribute to interdisciplinary transportation science. Students will be exposed to the interdisciplinary nature of transportation science and conduct research that has both theoretical and applied impact in various transportation areas. Students will learn a variety of behavioral science and engineering methods within human-in-the-loop simulation experiments, questionnaire-based behavioral research, and direct observation. Students will work closely with their faculty mentors on active research topics, such as automated driving systems, driver workload, distracted driving, pedestrian crossing behaviors and driver yielding responses, and pilot performance and trust in aircrafts. This project will help prepare students for higher education and careers in various transportation areas. 

The interdisciplinary transportation field enjoys theoretical developments in human perception and cognition, behavioral, engineering, public health and methodological areas to name a few, and is critical for reducing injuries and deaths resulting from motor vehicle crashes. This program will engage REU students in hands-on research activities in interdisciplinary transportation science in a 10-week summer program that will include research seminars, workshops, mentored research activities, and University sponsored poster session that are expected to shape the work into professional conference presentations and/or peer-reviewed publications. The program will offer training on research skills using driving and flight simulation, human performance modeling, eye tracking and field methods, among others. The REU program will also offer instructions in graduate school application and career development in transportation fields. The program will contribute to the development of researchers who advance transportation science with interdisciplinary, theory-driven, perspectives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

Award Title: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Research Experience in Behavioral Sciences of Transportation Issues

Director/PI: Yusuke Yamani

Award Number: 1949760 

 

In 2020, Old Dominion University received an REU Site award entitled “Interdisciplinary Research Experience in Behavioral Science of Transportation Issues.” This 10-week summer project successfully trained 24 undergraduate students in transportation research across a diverse set of disciplines including Psychology, Civil Engineering, Systems Engineering, Computer Science, Mathematics, and Simulation Engineering. The project achieved two main goals of the REU Site. 

Goal 1: Engaging Underrepresented and/or Underserved Undergraduate Students in Mentored Hands-On Research Activities in Transportation Science. Across the three years funded by this award, the program recruited 24 competitive undergraduate students nationwide. They comprised diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds in STEM. The proportion of the REU students with African-American or Hispanic background was 17%, 30%, and 50% in 2021, 2022, and 2023, respectively. All students were closely mentored by their mentors and graduate students for the entire cycle of scientific research including literature review, research methods, study execution, data analysis, and result interpretation and presentation. Each student was mentored by one or two ODU faculty mentor(s) from a variety of academic departments on an individual project. This enabled students to engage in independent work while also receiving continual feedback from their mentor. Research projects used a variety of different methods, including surveys, online empirical data collection, observational data collection, physiological and neural signal recording, and behavioral modeling, all key elements for interdisciplinary transportation science. Students presented their research projects both halfway through the program and at a final research symposium. The two symposia were held in the format similar to professional conferences with a specific timetable, providing the students with a unique opportunity to prepare and present their work in public. In addition to presenting at the symposia, students gained experience presenting on a smaller scale with their advisor and graduate students, allowing them to gain experience with active feedback and direct interaction with the audience, and improving and adapting the presentations as they were being developed.  In addition, students were actively encouraged to submit their research projects to national and local conferences to extend the impact of their work, some of which were accepted by international conferences and peer-reviewed journals. 

Goal 2: Helping Them to Pursue Advanced Degrees and Careers in Transportation Research and Industry. Students attended career pathways workshops to introduce them to government, non-profit, and private industry careers in transportation sciences. Field trips to the Virginia Department of Transportation (VDOT) office in Virginia Beach, VA, and NASA Langley Research Center, Hampton, VA, gave the REU students hands-on experience in surface transportation projects like highway traffic monitoring and design at VDOT and applied research projects from several labs at NASA Langley. Students also attended online symposia where scholars and researchers from the Japan Automobile Research Institute, University of Tsukuba, National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), University of Michigan Traffic Research Institute (UMTRI), and AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety gave lectures remotely, discussed the nature of their research, and provided insights on how students could pursue careers in transportation science in each sector. All sessions contained an interactive component where REU students asked questions directly to the presenters, assimilating professional interactions in the field of transportation safety. The program also implemented workshops that covered various methodologies that are employed by transportation researchers, which include simulator-based experimentation, physiological monitoring of driver cognitive state, and direct observation of traffic behaviors. To prepare students for pursuing careers in transportation sciences directly from undergraduate programs, professional development workshops were provided. The workshops were interactive, and students gained first-hand experience in how to develop effective resumes and cover letters, key elements to include on their personal website, and how to expand their professional networks.

Summary: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Research Experience in Behavioral Sciences of Transportation Issues at Old Dominion University successfully provided a set of hands-on research experiences and preparation for higher education and careers in various transportation areas. The program also contributed to the development of researchers who advance transportation science with interdisciplinary, theory-driven, perspectives.
